section.title: Variation of Parameters

assemblage.title: Straight to the point...
assemblage.p:
Variation of Parameters tells us that the ODE p(t) y'' + q(t) y' + r(t)y = g(t) has a particular solution Y(t) = u_1(t) y_1(t) + u_2(t) y_2(t), where
Y(t) = \int_{t_0}^t \frac{y_1(s) y_2(t) - y_1(t) y_2(s)}{W[y_1,y_2](s)} \cdot \frac{g(s)}{p(s)} \ ds.
Here, we take \{y_1, y_2\} to be a fundamental set of solutions of the homogeneous ODE p(t) y'' + q(t) y' + r(t)y = 0, that is to say, y_1 y_2' - y_1'y_2 \neq 0.
We also take t_0 to be some number that lies in the range of t that the ODE is defined on. Choosing an appropriate t_0 can sidestep a lot of the computational work.

Another way one can look at Variation of Parameters is that, given Y(t) = u_1(t) y_1(t) + u_2(t) y_2(t), the functions u_1 and u_2 satisfy the equation
\begin{bmatrix} y_1 \amp y_2 \\ y_1' \amp y_2' \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} u_1' \\ u_2' \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ g(t)/p(t) \end{bmatrix}.

Memorizing this (or the process below) is certainly less meticulous than memorizing the direct integral form above. Notice that the 2 \times 2 matrix on the left hand side above is the matrix whose determinant equals the W[y_1,y_2](t).

introduction.p:
We are often interested in finding a particular solution of a nonhomogenous linear ODE p(t) y'' + q(t) y' + r(t)y = g(t), mainly because the general solution of this ODE is
y(t) = h(t) + Y(t),
where h(t) is the general solution of the homogeneous linear ODE p(t) y'' + q(t) y' + r(t)y = 0 and Y(t) is any particular solution of the nonhomogeneous ODE p(t) y'' + q(t) y' + r(t)y = g(t).
Using Variation of Parameters or Duhamel's Principle helps us find some particular solution Y(t) for the nonhomogeneous ODE. Here, we'll start with Variation of Parameters.

subsection.title: Starting Variation of Parameters
subsection.p:
Variation of Parameters begins by assuming that a particular solution Y(t) to
p(t) y'' + q(t) y' + r(t)y = g(t)
is of the form
Y(t) = u_1(t) y_1(t) + u_2(t) y_2(t).
Here, y_1 and y_2 are fundamental solutions to the homogeneous ODE p(t) y'' + q(t) y' + r(t)y = 0, that is, the Wronskian W[y_1,y_2](t) \neq 0 for all applicable t.

proof.title: Review of Wronskian
proof.p:
Let y_1, y_2 be solutions of the homogeneous ODE p(t) y'' + q(t) y' + r(t)y = 0. Recall that the Wronskian of y_1, y_2 is denoted W[y_1, y_2](t), and
W[y_1, y_2](t) = \det \begin{bmatrix} y_1(t) \amp y_2(t) \\ y_1'(t) \amp y_2'(t) \end{bmatrix} = y_1(t) y_2'(t) - y_1'(t) y_2(t).

subsection.p: The idea behind Variation of Parameters is to kind of "generalize" the general solution of the homogenous ODE. Note that if we have that u_1(t) = c_1 and u_2(t) = c_2 are constant for all t, then the solution Y(t) = c_1 y_1(t) + c_2 y_2(t) is actually a solution of the homogeneous ODE!

So, we generalize the homogeneous solution by Y(t) = u_1(t) y_1(t) + u_2(t) y_2(t) in hopes that we find one (we only need one particular nonhomogeneous solution to describe them all!) solution to the nonhomogeneous ODE.
The algebra here can get a bit tricky, but I'll do my best to describe all the steps used!

section.subsection:
Equations involving u_1(t) and u_2(t)
Now, since Y(t) is a particular solution of p(t) y'' + q(t) y' + r(t)y = g(t), we have that
p(t) Y''(t) + q(t) Y'(t) + r(t)Y(t) = g(t).
We'll want to calculate Y'(t) and Y''(t), using the form Y(t) = u_1(t) y_1(t) + u_2(t) y_2(t). Doing so will create equations for u_1 and u_2, which we will hopefully be able to solve.
First, calculate Y'(t): (try it yourself! Remember that Y(t) = u_1 y_1 + u_2 y_2, all of those terms being functions of t.)
What's Y'(t) equal to?
We make good use of the product rule! Note that
Y'(t) \amp = \Big[ u_1'(t) y_1(t) + u_2'(t) y_2(t) \Big] + u_1(t) y_1'(t) + u_2(t) y_2'(t).
We have 4 terms in our representation of Y'(t). This means that Y''(t) will have 8 terms! To reduce down on the number of terms we have, we set
u_1'(t) y_1(t) + u_2'(t) y_2(t) = 0.
This may seem arbitrary for now, but this will ease up a lot of our calculations. We now have that
Y'(t) \amp = \Big[ u_1'(t) y_1(t) + u_2'(t) y_2(t) \Big] + u_1(t) y_1'(t) + u_2(t) y_2'(t) \amp = u_1(t) y_1'(t) + u_2(t) y_2'(t).
Now, we calculate Y''(t), using our representation of Y'(t) above.
What's Y''(t) equal to?
Again, this should be another quick differentiation exercise.
Y''(t) = \Big[ u_1'(t) y_1'(t) + u_2'(t) y_2'(t) \Big] + u_1(t) y_1''(t) + u_2(t) y_2''(t).
Now, we have expressions for Y'(t) and Y''(t). Substitute these into (Why isn't this working? This should expand out to show equation (1.1.1), will fix later). Doing so would yield that
u_1'(t) y_1'(t) + u_2'(t) y_2'(t) = \frac{g(t)}{p(t)}.
Why does this occur?
Since y_1 and y_2 are solutions of the homogeneous equation, notice that
p(t) y_1''(t) + q(t) y_1'(t) + r(t )y_1(t) = 0,
and
p(t) y_2''(t) + q(t) y_2'(t) + r(t )y_2(t) = 0.
Now, we directly substitute Y'(t) and Y''(t) into :
g(t) \amp = p(t) \Big[ u_1'(t) y_1'(t) + u_2'(t) y_2'(t) + u_1(t) y_1''(t) + u_2(t) y_2''(t) \Big] \amp \quad + \ q(t) \Big[ u_1(t) y_1'(t) + u_2(t) y_2'(t) \Big] \amp \quad + \ r(t) \Big[ u_1(t) y_1(t) + u_2(t) y_2(t) \Big],
\amp = u_1(t)\Big[ p(t) y_1''(t) + q(t) y_1'(t) + r(t )y_1(t) \Big] \amp \quad + \ u_2(t) \Big[ p(t) y_2''(t) + q(t) y_2'(t) + r(t )y_2(t) \Big] \amp \quad + \ p(t) \Big[ u_1'(t) y_1'(t) + u_2'(t) y_2'(t) \Big],
\amp = p(t) \Big[ u_1'(t) y_1'(t) + u_2'(t) y_2'(t) \Big].
Finish off by dividing p(t) on both sides. Note that we must have that p(t) \neq 0 for all t in the appropriate interval.
With this, we have finally found two equations involving u_1 and u_2, which we can solve as a typical system of linear equations:
u_1' y_1 + u_2' y_2 \amp = 0, u_1' y_1' + u_2' y_2' \amp = \frac{g(t)}{p(t)}.

subsection.title: Solving for u_1(t) and u_2(t)
subsection.p: We can write the two equations from the previous section as a matrix system.
With our knowledge from linear algebra, we can solve for u_1' and u_2' using matrix inverses:
At last! We have solved for u_1'(t) and u_2'(t):
We want u_1 and u_2. We can choose t_0 to be some number for which u_1(t_0) = 0 and u_2(t_0) = 0.

question.title: Why can we choose t_0 to satisfy u_1(t_0) = u_2(t_0) = 0?
question.p:
When we perform "indefinite integrals" we always have to add a constant to our answer (that "+ C"). For example, we would write
\int x^2 \ dx = \frac{x^3}3 + C.
In general, we have that
\int f'(x) \ dx = f(x) + C.
That is to say, given f'(x), we can find infinitely many unique f(x). As in the case before, any function of the form x^3/3 + C, for any constant C, has the derivative x^2

All this is to say that we know what u_1' and u_2' are. But, we can find infinitely many unique u_1 and u_2 whose derivatives satisfy the forms we have. So we can shift u_1 and u_2 up or down until both intersect at some t_0 with a value of 0.

subsection.p:
This helps us in that we can write that
u_1(t) = \int_{t_0}^t u_1'(s) \ ds = - \int_{t_0}^t \frac{y_2(s)}{W[y_1, y_2](s)} \frac{g(s)}{p(s)} \ ds,
and
u_2(t) = \int_{t_0}^t u_2'(s) \ ds = \int_{t_0}^t \frac{y_1(s)}{W[y_1, y_2](s)} \frac{g(s)}{p(s)} \ ds.

subsection.title: Final Form of Y(t)
subsection.p: With all this, our final form of Y(t) = u_1y_1 + u_2y_2 becomes

md.mrow: Y(t) = - y_1(t) \int_{t_0}^t \frac{y_2(s)}{W[y_1, y_2](s)} \frac{g(s)}{p(s)} \ ds + y_2(t) \int_{t_0}^t \frac{y_1(s)}{W[y_1, y_2](s)} \frac{g(s)}{p(s)} \ ds.

subsection.p: All in one integral, this is expressed as

This is the particular solution we obtain with Variation of Parameters! It's certainly a handful to memorize, but starting with Y = u_1y_1 + u_2y_2 and remembering the general steps we took along the way is another good way of remembering variation of parameters.

An interesting viewpoint of this is that we can write the general solution to a nonhomogeneous linear second order ODE of the form p(t) y'' + q(t) y' + r(t)y = g(t) using only a fundamental set of solutions \{y_1, y_2\} of the homogeneous ODE p(t) y'' + q(t) y' + r(t)y = 0, and a constant t_0 that lies in the interval the ODE is defined on.

Namely, the general solution of p(t) y'' + q(t) y' + r(t)y = g(t) is
y(t) = c_1y_1(t) + c_2y_2(t) + \int_{t_0}^t \frac{y_1(s) y_2(t) - y_1(t) y_2(s)}{W[y_1,y_2](s)} \cdot \frac{g(s)}{p(s)} \ ds,
where c_1,c_2 are real constants.

question.title: How to solve x'' - 4x = 0?
question.p: For 2nd order linear ODEs (basically ODEs of the form a x'' + bx' + cx = 0 for constants a,b,c), remember that we always start off by plugging in x = e^{rt}.
If x = e^{rt}, then x' = re^{rt} and x'' = r^2e^{rt}. Substituting these into x'' - 4x = 0 shows that
Dividing out by e^{rt} > 0 gives us the characteristic polynomial r^2 - 4 = 0. Solving this has solutions r = \pm 2. This means that e^{2t} and e^{-2t} are solutions of x'' - 4x = 0.
So, we get that x(t) = c_1 e^{2t} + c_2 e^{-2t} is the general solution of x'' - 4x = 0.

subsection.p: This makes it clear that we should take y_1(t) = e^{2t} and y_2(t) = e^{-2t}. The Wronskian W[y_1,y_2](t) = -4, so these are fundamental solutions.
All we need to find is a particular solution of x'' + 4x = e^t. This is quite easy if we've memorized the solution variation of parameters gives us.

subsection.title: Solve x'' - 3x' + 2x = 1
subsection.p: Try it yourself! First, solve x'' - 3x' + 2x = 0.

question.title: How do I solve x'' - 3x' + 2x = 0?
question.p:
Set x = e^{rt}. Substituting this into x'' - 3x' + 2x = 0 shows that
r^2 - 3r + 2 = 0.
This occurs when r = 1,2, so the general solution to x'' - 3x' + 2x = 0 is
x(t) = c_1e^t + c_2e^{2t}.

subsection.p: Next, we need a particular solution. Use variation of parameters to find some particular solution Y(t) of x'' - 3x' + 2x = 1.
